commit_message:
Potential resource exhaustion when registering consumers to containers

Previously, it was possible for consumers to be added with names of
arbitrary length. According to a finding by the Rackspace security
team, this ended up being a bigger problem than previously thought given
that addition of such consumers with sufficiently long names was apt to crash the running Barbican
instance.
Closes-Bug: 1430516

Change-Id: Ia5114d8de7dec796c56060892f389e47140c7834

commit_message:
AlarmStateTransitionedEvent timestamp now in ms

This will ensure a unique timestamp. Influx will only keep one
entry with the same timestamp

Change-Id: Ibf1001fea9328a6541381d344221b86e39996e1d

Recursively delete any region that has the supplied region as its parent. """ children = [r for r in self.list_regions(driver_hints.Hints()) if r['parent_region_id'] == region_id] for child in children: if child['id'] == root_region_id: # Hit a circular region hierarchy return self._delete_child_regions(child['id'], root_region_id) self._delete_region(child['id']) def _check_parent_region(self, region_ref): """Raise a NotFound if the parent region does not exist. If the region_ref has a specified parent_region_id, check that the parent exists, otherwise, raise a NotFound. """ parent_region_id = region_ref.get('parent_region_id') if parent_region_id is not None: # This will raise NotFound if the parent doesn't exist, # which is the behavior we want. self.get_region(parent_region_id) @deprecated() def create_region(self, region): region_id = region['id'] region.setdefault('parent_region_id') self._check_parent_region(region) self.db.set('region-%s' % region_id, region) region_list = set(self.db.get('region_list', [])) region_list.add(region_id) self.db.set('region_list', list(region_list)) return region @deprecated() def list_regions(self, hints): return [self.get_region(x) for x in self.db.get('region_list', [])] @deprecated() def get_region(self, region_id): return self.db.get('region-%s' % region_id) @deprecated() def update_region(self, region_id, region): self._check_parent_region(region) old_region = self.get_region(region_id) old_region.update(region) self._ensure_no_circle_in_hierarchical_regions(old_region) self.db.set('region-%s' % region_id, old_region) return old_region def _delete_region(self, region_id): self.db.delete('region-%s' % region_id) region_list = set(self.db.get('region_list', [])) region_list.remove(region_id) self.db.set('region_list', list(region_list)) @deprecated() def delete_region(self, region_id): self._delete_child_regions(region_id, region_id) self._delete_region(region_id) # service crud @deprecated() def create_service(self, service_id, service): self.db.set('service-%s' % service_id, service) service_list = set(self.db.get('service_list', [])) service_list.add(service_id) self.db.set('service_list', list(service_list)) return service @deprecated() def list_services(self, hints): return [self.get_service(x) for x in self.db.get('service_list', [])] @deprecated() def get_service(self, service_id): return self.db.get('service-%s' % service_id) @deprecated() def update_service(self, service_id, service): old_service = self.get_service(service_id) old_service.update(service) self.db.set('service-%s' % service_id, old_service) return old_service @deprecated() def delete_service(self, service_id): # delete referencing endpoints for endpoint_id in self.db.get('endpoint_list', []): if self.get_endpoint(endpoint_id)['service_id'] == service_id: self.delete_endpoint(endpoint_id) self.db.delete('service-%s' % service_id) service_list = set(self.db.get('service_list', [])) service_list.remove(service_id) self.db.set('service_list', list(service_list)) # endpoint crud @deprecated() def create_endpoint(self, endpoint_id, endpoint): self.get_service(endpoint['service_id']) self.db.set('endpoint-%s' % endpoint_id, endpoint) endpoint_list = set(self.db.get('endpoint_list', [])) endpoint_list.add(endpoint_id) self.db.set('endpoint_list', list(endpoint_list)) return endpoint @deprecated() def list_endpoints(self, hints): return [self.get_endpoint(x) for x in self.db.get('endpoint_list', [])] @deprecated() def get_endpoint(self, endpoint_id): return self.db.get('endpoint-%s' % endpoint_id) @deprecated() def update_endpoint(self, endpoint_id, endpoint): if endpoint.get('region_id') is not None: self.get_region(endpoint['region_id']) old_endpoint = self.get_endpoint(endpoint_id) old_endpoint.update(endpoint) self.db.set('endpoint-%s' % endpoint_id, old_endpoint) return old_endpoint @deprecated() def delete_endpoint(self, endpoint_id): self.db.delete('endpoint-%s' % endpoint_id) endpoint_list = set(self.db.get('endpoint_list', [])) endpoint_list.remove(endpoint_id) self.db.set('endpoint_list', list(endpoint_list)) # Private interface def _create_catalog(self, user_id, tenant_id, data): self.db.set('catalog-%s-%s' % (tenant_id, user_id), data) return data

commit_message:
Deal with PEP-0476 certificate chaining checking

PEP-0476 introduced more thorough certificate chain verfication
for HTTPS connectivity; this was introduced in Python 2.7.9, and
breaks a number of unit tests in the cinder codebase.

Disable certificate chain verification for cinder SSL tests
using the backwards compatible SSLContext provided for this
purpose.

Closes-Bug: #1403068
(cherry picked from commit 4e849ef5fbb7159276435ac6f7315bf20274768d)

Conflicts:
	cinder/tests/test_wsgi.py

Change-Id: Iffc3658196f608c7a7c9b6527dc8e7210fb05bff
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/63/166263/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import fixtures for var in ('http_proxy', 'HTTP_PROXY'): self.useFixture(fixtures.EnvironmentVariable(var))

commit_message:
Ignore HTTP_PROXY during test requests

urllib2 follows http_proxy/HTTP_PROXY by default.  If a (non-local)
proxy is set and a test tries to connect to localhost:$port, it will
instead attempt to connect to $port on the proxy and (presumably) fail.

This change forces the two tests that failed in the presence of
HTTP_PROXY to connect directly.

Change-Id: Ia12c91b356f0ccebf874933ff459aa2faa190655
(cherry picked from commit b0ebfb90958afac39be24b5157763d479256ab8c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/68/166268/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import fixtures for var in ('http_proxy', 'HTTP_PROXY'): self.useFixture(fixtures.EnvironmentVariable(var))

commit_message:
Add documentation for Ironic config file

Change-Id: Ia10455d9db89b171fd27e4cad8bd6ad36f482df2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/77/83577/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ========================= Ironic Configuration File ========================= Introduction ============ Ironic is configured via its ironic.conf file, typically located in /etc/ironic/. It is organized into several sections. Default ======= The **[DEFAULT]** section of the file configures overall defaults for Ironic. my_ip The IP address of the host running Ironic. If unset, the default is FIXME. use_ipv6 A Boolean value indicating whether IPv6 should be used or not. It defaults to FIXME. auth_strategy The authentication strategy used by the API. Accepted values are "noauth" or "keystone". If set to "keystone", Keystone will be used for documentation. "noauth" will disable all authentication, and should not be used in a production environment. fatal_exception_format_errors I have no idea what this does. FIXME! hash_partition_exponent Exponent to determine number of hash partitions to use when distributing load across conductors. Larger values will result in more even distribution of load and less load when rebalancing the ring, but more memory usage. Number of partitions is (2^hash_partition_exponent). (integer value) hash_distribution_replicas Number of hosts to map onto each hash partition. Setting this to more than one will cause additional conductor services to prepare deployment environments and potentially allow the Ironic cluster to recover more quickly if a conductor instance is terminated. (integer value) force_raw_images It true, images backing Ironic deployments will be coerced into raw format. (FIXME: what does this mean? Why would a user want one?) pybasedir Explicitly set the directory where the Ironic Python module is installed. bindir Explicitly set the directory in which the Ironic binaries are installed. state_path Explicitly set the top-level directory where Ironic's state is kept. policy_file A JSON file representing policy. (FIXME: What type of policy? When would a user modifty this?) policy_default_rule Sets what rule should be checked when the requested rule is not found. periodic_interval The number of seconds between runs of periodic tasks. host The name of the Ironic node. Using a hostname or IP address is recommended, but not mandatory. It must be a valid AMQP key name. If using ZeroMQ, this value must be a valid hostname, FQDN, or IP address. rootwrap_config A path to the rootwrap configuration file (used to restrict which commands can be run as root.) tempdir Used to explicitly set the temporary working directory. sqlite_db If using SQLite, the path to the SQLite database file. sqlite_synchronous A Boolean toggle indicating whether SQLite should operate in synchronous mode. backdoor_port The port on which the Eventlet backdoor listens. (FIXME: I think this defaults to None? What does that mean? No listener?) disable_process_locking If set to true, inter-process locking is disabled. lock_path The directory in which lock files are stored. Logging ------- debug Toggles debug output. If true, the logging level is set to DEBUG. If false (the default), the log level is kept at WARNING. verbose Toggles verbose output. If true, the logging level is set to INFO. If false, the log level is kept at WARNING. FIXME: What if debug and verbose are both enabled? use_stderr Enables logging output to STDERR (standard error). logging_context_format_string A Python format string used for log messages with context. An example value is :: %(asctime)s.%(msecs)03d %(process)d %(levelname)s %(name)s [%(request_id)s %(user)s %(tenant)s] %(instance)s%(message)s FIXME: Is there a place that defines which variables are available? logging_default_format_string A Python format string used for log messages without context. An example value is :: %(asctime)s.%(msecs)03d %(process)d %(levelname)s %(name)s [-] %(instance)s%(message)s logging_debug_format_suffix A Python format string defining data appended to the log when in DEBUG mode. An example setting is ``%(funcName)s %(pathname)s:%(lineno)d`` logging_exception_prefix A Python format string defining data prepended to the log when exceptions occur. An example value is ``%(asctime)s.%(msecs)03d %(process)d TRACE %(name)s %(instance)s`` default_log_levels A Python list of available loggers and their syslog levels. For example, ``amqp=WARN,keystone=INFO`` would cause AMQP messages to be logged with WARN priority, while Keystone messages would be logged at the more verbose INFO level. Available loggers include 'amqp', 'amqplib', 'boto', 'keystone', 'qpid', 'sqlalchemy', 'suds', and 'iso8601'. FIXME: That is just what's in the file; is that complete? publish_errors Toggles whether error events are published. FIXME: published where? What is the effect of htis setting? fatal_deprecations If set to true, deprecation warnings are treated as fatal exceptions. FIXME: Where? Just in the logs? instance_format A Python format string used to format log messages when an instance is passed in. For example, ``"[instance: %(uuid)s] "`` instance_uuid_format A Python format string used to format instance UUIDs when passed to a log message. For example, ``"[instance: %(uuid)s] "`` FIXME: How else _would_ you format a UUID? Omit it? log_config_append FIXME: Is this deprecated? The comments confuse me. FIXME: This text is a literal copy-and-paste and I don't understand. The name of logging configuration file. It does not disable existing loggers, but just appends specified logging configuration to any other existing logging options. Please see the Python logging module documentation for details on logging configuration files. (string value) Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/log_config log_format **This option is deprecated.** Use ``logging_context_format_string`` and ``logging_default_format_string`` instead. This option was a format string used for log entries. log_date_format A Python format string used for timestamps in log records. For example, ``%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S`` log_file The name of the log file Ironic writes to. If no location is set, STDOUT will be used. log_dir The base directory used when a relative ``--log-file`` path is set. use_syslog A Boolean toggling whether output goes to syslog. syslog_log_facility The syslog facility that receives log entries. Defaults to LOG_USER. Notifications ------------- notification_driver The driver(s) used to handle sending notifications. default_notification_level The default notification level for outgoing notifications. The default value is INFO. default_publisher_id The default publisher_id value for outgoing notifications. notification_topics The AMQP topic(s) used for OpenStack notifications. Periodic tasks -------------- run_external_periodic_tasks Toggles whether to run periodic tasks in separate processes where possible. RPC settings ------------ Ironic implements a pluggable RPC interface. Supported interfaces include Qpid, RabbitMQ, Kombu, ZeroMQ, and Matchmaker. The interface used can be configured in ``rpc_backend`` (see below). Subsections below outline the per-backend configuration options available. rpc_backend The messaging module to use for RPC notifications. The default value is rpc.impl_kombu. rpc_thread_pool_size The number of threads in the RPC thread pool. rpc_conn_pool_size The size of the RPC connection pool. rpc_response_timeout The (integer) number of seconds to wait for a response to RPC calls or multicalls. rcp_cast_timeout The (integer) number of seconds before a cast TTL expires. This option is only supported by impl_zmq. allowed_rpc_exception_modules Modules of exceptions listed here will be permitted to be recreated when they are received during an RPC call. This setting is a list, such as ``nova.exception,cinder.exception,exceptions``. fake_rabbit If enabled, a fake RabbitMQ provider is used. FIXME: Why? Debug? AMQP .... control_exchange The AMQP exchange to which Ironic connects when using RabbitMQ or Qpid. amqp_durable_queues A Boolean toggling whether durable queues are used in AMQP. amqp_auto_delete A Boolean toggling whether to auto-delete queues in AMQP. Kombu ..... These settings are specific to the Kombu RPC implementation. These SSL settings will have no effect unless SSL is enabled. kombu_ssl_version The SSL version used, if SSL is enabled. Valid values are TLSv1, SSLv23, and SSLv3. Certain distributions may also recognize SSLv2. kombu_ssl_keyfile The SSL key file used by Kombu. kombu_ssl_certfile The SSL certificate file used by Kombu. kombu_ssl_ca_certs A string pointing to the SSL Certificate Authority (CA) file. RabbitMQ ........ These settings are specific to RabbitMQ usage. Use of either a single RabbitMQ server, or multiple RabbitMQ servers, is possible. In the case of a single server, rabbit_host and rabbit_port should be set. For multiple servers, use rabbit_hosts. FIXME: Why not just always use rabbit_hosts, even if it's a single-item list? See http://docs.openstack.org/grizzly/openstack-compute/admin/content/configuring-rpc.html for more. rabbit_host The RabbitMQ broker address, for a single-server setup. rabbit_port The RabbitMQ broker port, if using only a single broker. rabbit_hosts A list of host:port mappings of RabbitMQ servers. rabbit_use_ssl A Boolean determining whether SSL should be used. rabbit_userid The RabbitMQ user ID. rabbit_password The RabbitMQ password. rabbit_virtual_host The virtual host used for RabbitMQ. rabbit_retry_interval How frequenly (an integer number of seconds) to retry connections to RabbitMQ. rabbit_retry_backoff The backoff duration between retries connecting to RabbitMQ. FIXME: How is this different? Is this an exponential backoff, or does it duplicate rabbit_retry_interval? rabbit_max_retries : integer The maximum number of connection retries to RabbitMQ. Set to 0 (the default value) for unlimited retries. rabbit_ha_queues : Boolean Toggles whether to use HA queues (x-ha-policy: all) in RabbitMQ. Changing this option requires wiping the RabbitMQ database. Qpid .... These settings govern the Qpid AMQP driver. Ironic supports using a single Qpid server, or a cluster of multiple servers. Use qpid_hostname and qpid_port for a single server setup, or qpid_hosts for a cluster. FIXME: Could we just use qpid_hosts always? qpid_hostname : String The Qpid broker hostname (if using a single server). qpid_port : Integer The Qpid port number (if using a single server). qpid_hosts : List A list of hostname:port mappings used in a Qpid cluster. qpid_username : String The username used for the Qpid connection. qpid_password : String The password used for the Qpid connection. qpid_sasl_mechanisms : String A space-separated list of SALS mechanisms used for authentication. FIXME: Can we give the user a list?? FIXME: Why not use a list?! qpid_heartbeat : Integer The number of seconds between keepalive heartbeats sent on the Qpid connection. qpid_protocol : String The transport method used for our Qpid connection. Accepted values are 'ssl' or 'tcp'. qpid_tcp_nodelay : Boolean Disables the Nagle algorithm (TCP nodelay). qpid_topology_version : Integer The Qpid topology version to use. Accepted values are 1 and 2. New users should use Version 2, as it allows broker federation. The changes in Version 2 are not backwards-compatible with Version 1, so existing users of Version 1 will need to shut down all Qpid services before upgrading. ZeroMQ ...... ZeroMQ is another AMQP interface available. FIXME: Where would someone _select_ which to use? rpc_zmq_bind_address : String The bind address for ZeroMQ. This setting should be a wildcard (*), an Ethernet interface, or an IP address. The ``host`` option should contain a value which maps to this address. rpc_zmq_matchmaker : String The MatchMaker driver. The default value is: :: ironic.openstack.common.rpc.matchmaker.MatchMakerLocalhost FIXME: expand on this! rcp_zmq_port : Integer : Default 9501 The port on which ZeroMQ's receiver listens. rpc_zmq_contexts : Integer : 1 The number of ZeroMQ contexts. FIXME what does that mean? rcp_zmq_topic_backlog : Integer : Default None The maximum number of ingress messages that are locally buffered for a given topic. Set to None (default) for unlimited. rpc_zmq_ipc_dir : String : /var/run/openstack The directory where ZeroMQ can hold IPC sockets. rpc_zmq_host : String The name of this ZeroMQ node, which must be a valid hostname, FQDN, or IP address. If using Nova, this must match the ``host`` option. Matchmaker .......... FIXME: I have no idea what this is. matchmaker_heartbeat_freq : Integer : Default 300 The heartbeat frequency used for Matchmaker. matchmaker_heartbeat_ttl : Integer : Default 600 The Matchmaker heartbeat Time to Live. FIXME: What does that mean? What happens when it runs out? API === The settings in the **[api]** section of the documentation govern the Ironic API service. host_ip : String : Default 0.0.0.0 The IP on which the Ironic API server listens. port : Integer : Default 6385 The TCP port on which the Ironic API server listens. max_limit : Integer : Default 1000 The maximum number of items returned in a single response from a collection resource. Conductor ========= The **[conductor]** section of the Ironic configuration file governs the behavior of the Ironic Conductor service. api_url : String : Default None The URL of the Ironic API service. By default, this value is not set and is instead retrieved from the Keystone service catalog. Explicitly define here to override. heartbeat_interval : Integer : 10 The number of seconds to wait between Conductor heartbeats. heartbeat_timeout : Integer : 60 The number of seconds that can elapse since the last check-in of a Conductor before FIXME. sync_power_state_interval : Integer : 60 The number of seconds between checks of node power state, which are synchronized to the database. check_provision_state_interval : Integer : 60 The number of seconds between checks for provision timeouts. deploy_callback_timeout : Integer : 1800 The number of seconds before a timeout is raised while waiting for a callback from a deploy ramdisk. Set to 0 to disable timeout. force_power_state_during_sync : Boolean : True When sync_power_state runs, if this option is enabled, the hardware power state will be made to match the contents of the database. (That is, if a node is marked as being powered on in the database and is found to be powered off during the check, it will be powered on.) If set to False, the opposite happens: the database is updated to match the actual state of the hardware. Database ======== backend : String : sqlalchemy The backend to use for database connections, defaulting to sqlalchemy. FIXME: what other options are there? mysql_engine : String : InnoDB If MySQL is used, this sets which storage engine is used, defaulting to InnoDB. use_tpool : Boolean : False Enables the **experimental** use of thread pooling for all database calls. sqlite_db : String : Default ironic.sqlite The file name for the SQLite database. sqlite_synchronous : Boolean : Default True Toggles whether SQlite operates in synchronous mode. connection : String The string passed to SQLAlchemy to be used for the database connection. mysql_sql_mode : String : None The SQL mode used for MySQL connections. The default value is None, which means that the server-side SQL mode setting is used. FIXME: What are possible vlaues here? idle_timeout : Integer : Default 3600 The number of seconds before idle SQL connections are reaped. Connection Pools ---------------- min_pool_size : Integer : Default 1 The minimum number of SQL connections maintained in a connection pool. max_pool_size : Integer : Default None The maximum number of SQL connections that can be maintained in a connection pool. max_retries : Integer : Default 10 The maximum number of database connection retries. The value -1 will cause infinite retries. retry_interval : Integer : Default 10 The number of seconds to wait between attempts at opening a database connection (retries). SQLAlchemy Settings ------------------- If using the SQLAlchemy backend, these settings will be passed in to control the connections. max_overflow : Integer : Default None This optional value is passed to SQLAlchemy for its max_overflow setting. FIXME: And that means...? connection_debug : Integer An integer, ranging from 0 to 100, determining how verbose the SQL logging should be. 0 causes no logging, while 100 is maximally verbose. connection_trace : Boolean : Default False Enable Python stack traces to SQL commands as comment strings. pool_timeout : Integer : Default None The pool timeout, in seconds, used with SQLAlchemy connection pools. use_db_reconnect : Boolean : Default False **Experimental**. Enables use of automatic reconnections when the connection to the database is lost. FIXME: That's not already happening? db_retry_interval : Integer : Default 1 The number of seconds ot wait between database connection retries. FIXME: How is this different from retry_interval? db_inc_retry_interval : Boolean : Default True Toggles whether the interval between database connection retries should increase with successive failures. The increase will not exceed the setting in db_max_retry_interval. db_max_retry_interval : Integer : Default 10 The maximum number of seconds between database connection retries. db_max_retries : Integer : Default 20 The maximum number of database connection retries that will be made before raising an error. Set to -1 for infinite retries. Glance ====== Glance is the image store used by Ironic. The **[glance]** section of the configuration file permits modification of these files. allowed_direct_url_schemes: List A list of URL schemes that can be directly downloaded with a direct URL. Presently, ``[file]`` is the only supported scheme. FIXME: Verify this. glance_host : String The hostname or IP where Glance can be reached. Defaults to the same IP as Ironic. glance_port : Integer : Default 9292 The TCP port on which Glance listens. glance_protocol : String : Default http The default protocol used when connecting to Glance. Accepted values are 'http' or 'https'. glance_api_servers : String A list of Glance API servres available to Nova. The format is ``[hostname|ip]:port``, but should be prefixed with 'https://' if use of SSL is desired. FIXME: Is this just the plural of glance_host and glance_port? Are the square braces on [hostname|ip] literal, or do they denote optionality? glance_api_insecure : Boolean Allow performing insecure SSL (HTTPS) requests to Glance. FIXME: What does that mean? No cert validation? glance_num_retries : Integer The number of retries that will be attempted when downloading an image from Glance. auth_strategy : String The authentication strategy used for connecting to Glance. Accepted values are 'keystone' (to use Keystone for authentication) and 'noauth' (to disable authentication). IPMI ==== The options in the **[ipmi]** section govern Ironic's interactions with IPMI-enabled hosts. They apply onto the ipminative driver, not to the ipmitool driver. (FIXME: verify that I didn't just make that up.) retry_timeout : Integer : Default 10 The number of seconds to wait before retrying an IPMI operation. Keystone Authtoken ================== The **[keystone_authtoken]** section of the configuration file allows customization of Ironic's handling of authentication tokens ("auth tokens") from Keystone. auth_admin_prefix : String An optional string that is prepended to the beginning of the path. FIXME: What does this mean? auth_host : String : Default 127.0.0.1 The hostname or IP address of the admin Identity API endpoint. auth_port : Integer : Default 35357 The TCP port of the admin identity API endpoint. auth_protocol : String : Default https The protocol used to communicate with the admin Identity API endpoint. Accepted values are 'http' or 'https'. auth_uri : String The complete URI to the public Identity API endpoint. auth_version : String API version of the admin Identity API endpoint. delay_auth_decision : Boolean : Default False If enabled, authorization requests are not handled in middleware. Instead, the downstream WSGI components are delegated with this responsbility. http_connect_timeout : FIXME FIXME: This shows up as a Boolean, which doesn't make much sense. http_request_max_retries : Integer : Default 3 The number of reconnect attempts made when communicating with the Identity API service. http_handler : String This setting is primarily for developer testing, not end users. It allows use of a fake ``http_handler`` callback function instead of the standard ``httplib.HTTPConnection`` (or ``HTTPSConnection``).a admin_token : String An optional shared secret beween Keystone and Ironic, used for bootstrapping a Keystone installation. it is also used to bypass the normal authentication process. It should not be used in production environments. admin_user : String The Keystone account username. FIXME: What if this is blank (default)? Read from the user's session? admin_password : String The password for the account specified in admin_user. admin_tenant_name : String : Default admin The tenant name used by Keystone to validate user tokens. cache : String FIXME: The documentation calls this the Swift cache. certfile : String The path to an SSL client certificate, in the event that Keystone is configured to require one. keyfile : String The path to an SSL keyfile, in the event that Keystone is configured to require client certificates. cafile : String A PEM-encoded Certificate Authority (CA) to use when verifying HTTPS connections. If unset, the default behavior is to use the system CAs. insecure : String If enabled, disables verification of HTTPS connections. signing_dir : String A directory in which cache files pertaining to PKI tokens can be stored. memcached_servers : List An optional list of one or more memcached servers used for caching tokens. token_cache_time : Integer : Default 300 Used only if ``memcached_servers`` is defined. This value is the number of seconds a token should be cached. This is done by the middleware to prevent excessive requests against Keystone's API. Setting this value to -1 will disable caching completely. revocation_cache_time : Integer : Default 1 This setting is used only by developers in unit tests. It should not be used in production environments. memcache_security_strategy : String An optional token controller how token data is stored in memcache. If set to "MAC", token data is not encrypted, but is authenticated with HMAC in the cache. If set to "ENCRYPT", token data is both encrypted and authenticated in the cache. memcache_secret_key : String This field is required only if ``memcache_security_strategy`` is defined. It is used for key derivation. FIXME: that is meaninglessly vague to an end user. What should they put here? include_service_catalog : Boolean An optional field to set the ``X-Service-Catalog`` header on token validation, which causes Keystone to include its service catalog in responses. FIXME: WHy would a uesr care? enforce_token_bind : String : Default permissive This controls the type of token binding. (FIXME: And that means..?) This has numerous possible values: * "disabled" -- Token binding is not checked. * "permissive" -- Binding information is validated if the bind type is known to the server. Otherwise, it is not checked. This is the default setting. * "strict" -- As with "permissive," but with unknown bind types rejected instead of ignored. * "required" -- Token binding (of any form) is required. * The name of a binding method may also be supplied, If so, it must be present in tokens. Matchmaker ========== The Matchmaker service (FIXME) has two sections of the file: Matchmaker Redis ---------------- The settings in **[matchmaker_redis]** control Matchmaker's interface to Redis. The following options can be configured: host : String : Default 127.0.0.1 The hostname where the Redis server runs. port : Integer : Default 6379 The port on which Redis listens. password : String An optional password used to connect to Redis. Matchmaker Ring --------------- The **[matchmaker_ring]** section current contains only a single entry: ringfile : String The full path to a Matchmaker ring file (JSON). Neutron ======= The **[neutron]** section of the Ironic configuration file contains settings for Neutron, the Openstack networking service. url : String : Default http://127.0.0.1:9696 FIXME: Make RST not auto-link that. The HTTP URL for connecting to Neutron. It should include both a hostname and a port. url_timeout : Integer : Default 30 The number of seconds before which the Neutron connection times out. PXE === The following options are available to configure how PXE (network boot) is used. pxe_append_params : String : Default: nofb nomodeset vga=normal Define parameters appended to the Linux boot string. pxe_config_template : String : Default: $pybasedir/drivers/modules/pxe_config.template Set to change the template file used for PXE configuration. tftp_server : String : Default: $my_ip The IP address of the TFTP server Ironic will use. tftp_root : String : Default: /tftpboot The root path for the TFTP server. images_path : String : Default: /var/lib/ironic/images/ The directory where images are stored on disk. FIXME: By the agent, or by Conductor? tftp_master_path : String: Default: /tftpboot/master_images The directory where master TFTP images are stored. instance_master_path : String : Default: /var/lib/ironic/master_images The directory where master instance images are stored. pxe_bootfile_name : String : Default: pxelinux.0 The bootfile DHCP parameter used by Neutron. RPC Notifier ============ The **[rpc_notifier2]** section of the Ironic configuration file is used to configure the rpc_notifier2 notifications module. It exposes only one setting: topics : List : Default: notifications The AMQP topic(s) used for OpenStack notifications. SeaMicro Driver =============== The **[seamicro]** configuration section allows customizing settings for the SeaMicro driver. max_retry : Integer : Default: 3 Maximum number of retries to make for SeaMicro operations. action_timeout : Integer : Default: 10 The number of seconds to wait for a power action to be completed. SSH Driver ========== The **[ssh]** section allows configuring the ssh driver. libvirt_uri : String : Default: qemu:///system Allows customizing the libvirt URI. SSL === The **[ssl]** section allows configuring SSL parameters used in Ironic. ca_file : String : Default: None The CA certificate file used for verifying connectin clients. cert_file : String : Default: None The certificate file used for SSL connections. key_file : String : Default: None The private key file used by the server for SSL connections.

commit_message:
Use openstack CLI instead of keystone

When running './stack.sh' messages are output stating that
the keystone CLI has been deprecated. These calls should be
replaced to ones utilizing the openstack CLI program instead.

Documentation examples were also updated to reflect the new syntax.

Change-Id: Ib20b8940e317d150e5f6febb618e20bd85d13f8b
Closes-Bug: #1441340

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-11 22:47:47.000000000', 'files': ['clean.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/93d09c24e35611cc7fc1ef8e6796d177d460fecc', 'message': 'Setting LOGFILE to a file in root directory wipes everything

clean.sh picks the parent of LOGFILE and wipes it clean! So if you
set it to a log file in the users root directory, you lose everything

Change-Id: I45745427dcaed3dcf0b78cc9ed680833d9d555e8

commit_message:
Setting LOGFILE to a file in root directory wipes everything

clean.sh picks the parent of LOGFILE and wipes it clean! So if you
set it to a log file in the users root directory, you lose everything

We should delete just the LOGFILE and cleanup LOGDIR and SCREEN_LOGDIR if
they are explicitly set.

Change-Id: I45745427dcaed3dcf0b78cc9ed680833d9d555e8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/86/172686/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Clean out data and status sudo rm -rf $DATA_DIR $DEST/status # Clean out the log file and log directories if [[ -n "$LOGFILE" ]] && [[ -f "$LOGFILE" ]]; then sudo rm -f $LOGFILE fi if [[ -n "$LOGDIR" ]] && [[ -d "$LOGDIR" ]]; then sudo rm -rf $LOGDIR fi
deleted_lines: # Clean out data, logs and status LOGDIR=$(dirname "$LOGFILE") sudo rm -rf $DATA_DIR $LOGDIR $DEST/status

commit_message:
Recap ceilometerclient for stable/icehouse

ceilometerclient's stable/icehouse branch has 1.0.12, and since the
requirement was <=1.0.12 we can't create patches since they get
a version like 1.0.12.post1

Change-Id: Ic27aa88085656298a91001f9a95686d3031ea7ac

commit_message:
Add support for arm64 images

This patch enables proper support for arm64 images by disabling VNC support
and adding several properties to the image in glance that are necessary to
boot correctly:
  hw_cdrom_bus=virtio
  hw_machine_type=virt
  os_command_line='console=ttyAMA0'

Change-Id: I68c9a5e0e083af2f92875c3bdf70df750f6e4d8f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/00/171300/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # arm64-specific configuration if is_arch "aarch64"; then # arm64 architecture currently does not support graphical consoles. iniset $NOVA_CONF DEFAULT vnc_enabled "false" fi

commit_message:
LPAR-specific SSP ops target VIOSes on same host

When nova is managing an SSP Cluster whose VIOSes span multiple
accessible hosts (e.g. nova is running against a single HMC managing
multiple hosts), it is important that operations specific to a
particular instance - such as creating and removing disk connections -
be invoked only on the VIOS(es) residing on the same host as that
instance.  This change set fixes the SSP Disk Driver to ensure this is
the case.

Ancillary to this change is an expansion and refactoring of the vm
utility to retrieve quick properties for an LPAR.  Invoking the new
vm.get_vm_qp method without the qprop parameter will return a dictionary
of all the quick properties available for the LPAR.

Change-Id: Ib1d02743baf041c9abc69b25201d33e516fa6cb3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm refs/changes/46/174146/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import json return get_vm_qp(self._adapter, self._uuid, q_prop) return get_vm_qp(adapter, lpar_uuid, qprop='PartitionID') def get_vm_qp(adapter, lpar_uuid, qprop=None): """Returns one or all quick properties of an LPAR. :param adapter: The pypowervm adapter. :param lpar_uuid: The (powervm) UUID for the LPAR. :param qprop: The quick property key to return. If specified, that single property value is returned. If None/unspecified, all quick properties are returned in a dictionary. :return: Either a single quick property value or a dictionary of all quick properties. """ try: resp = adapter.read(pvm_lpar.LPAR.schema_type, root_id=lpar_uuid, suffix_type='quick', suffix_parm=qprop) except pvm_exc.Error as e: if e.response.status == 404: raise exception.InstanceNotFound(instance_id=lpar_uuid) else: LOG.exception(e) raise return json.loads(resp.body)
deleted_lines: try: resp = self._adapter.read( pvm_lpar.LPAR.schema_type, root_id=self._uuid, suffix_type='quick', suffix_parm=q_prop) except pvm_exc.Error as e: if e.response.status == 404: raise exception.InstanceNotFound(instance_id=self._name) else: LOG.exception(e) raise return resp.body.lstrip(' "').rstrip(' "') return adapter.read(pvm_lpar.LPAR.schema_type, root_id=lpar_uuid, suffix_type='quick', suffix_parm='PartitionID').body

commit_message:
Replace httplib with requests in the http store

By replacing Httplib with requests we forward most of
HTTP heavy lifting to a well tested library and in the same
time we gain new feature like proxy awareness in case glance
was deployed behind a proxy.

Change-Id: I1987b0814e7a349acd60ae8b4ccdee61108f9d8d

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-api refs/changes/73/172673/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: private final boolean gzip; logger.debug("Influxdb database name: {}", this.influxName); logger.debug("Influxdb URL: {}", this.influxUrl); this.gzip = config.influxDB.getGzip(); logger.debug("Influxdb gzip responses: {}", this.gzip); logger.debug("Setting up basic Base64 authentication"); // We inject InfluxV9RepoReader as a singleton. So, we must share connections safely. if (this.gzip) { logger.debug("Setting up gzip responses from Influxdb"); this.httpClient = HttpClients.custom().setConnectionManager(cm) .addInterceptorFirst(new HttpRequestInterceptor() { public void process(final HttpRequest request, final HttpContext context) throws HttpException, IOException { if (!request.containsHeader("Accept-Encoding")) { request.addHeader("Accept-Encoding", "gzip"); } } }).addInterceptorFirst(new HttpResponseInterceptor() { public void process(final HttpResponse response, final HttpContext context) throws HttpException, IOException { HttpEntity entity = response.getEntity(); if (entity != null) { Header ceheader = entity.getContentEncoding(); if (ceheader != null) { HeaderElement[] codecs = ceheader.getElements(); for (int i = 0; i < codecs.length; i++) { if (codecs[i].getName().equalsIgnoreCase("gzip")) { response.setEntity(new GzipDecompressingEntity(response.getEntity())); return; } } } } } }).build(); } else { logger.debug("Setting up non-gzip responses from Influxdb"); this.httpClient = HttpClients.custom().setConnectionManager(cm).build(); } logger.debug("Received {} status code from influx database {} at {}", rc, this.influxName, this.influxUrl); logger .error("Failed to query influx database {} at {}: {}", this.influxName, this.influxUrl, String.valueOf(rc)); logger .debug("Successfully queried influx database {} at {}", this.influxName, this.influxUrl);

commit_message:
print user friendly error message for alarm update time constraints

Currently, if we update an alarm with wrong time constraint which
doesn't get name defined, then the shell only prints a very simple
string 'name'.

This is because our code assume name field has always been specified,
however it is not true, then KeyError exception will be raised but not
handled well, finally user only gets an implicit message.

This patch uses dict.get() for name field, and sends request (may be broken)
to ceilometer api, then extracts error message from response.

Change-Id: I086c4ec790acc22767ba7f5e43dbcf73f3af5dff
Closes-Bug: #1439207

commit_message:
Improve logging in fixed_networks

This commit makes some logging improvements to the common methods in
fixed_networks.py. Previously it was very difficult to trace through
any issues around network selection since it only would log the final
result and on failures. It also didn't attribute any messages to the
tests making the call. This fixes both issues by first leveraging
find_test_caller() from tempest-lib to get the test caller name and
secondly add more logging to help trace through the logic if something
fails. Additionally as part of this it was necessary to add additional
checks to the logic to ensure the logging was accurate and things were
in a known state.

Change-Id: Ifef67ed4578f48d7701635e7d81c144dc28b6120

commit_message:
Check to see if instance kwarg is a string

The instance_format config option needs a uuid kwarg for formatting but
the instance kwarg value can be a string uuid or instance dict/object
which contains a 'uuid' key/attribute.

Update the code to handle the instance_format config option formatting
for both string and dict/object values.

Closes-Bug: #1444728

Change-Id: I177de104bfeaee6c0769d5c0c02f32fa7bc3f12c

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-14 09:12:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/fbd3c13d1e49c76fd7935046609b34954fcaa88d', 'message': 'Move ComputeNode creation at init stage in ResourceTracker

This is the first step in a series refactoring code that uses
ResourceTracker.compute_node so that it can later be changed
to be a ComputeNode object. Note that in this patch compute_node
is still a dict.

The main refactor in this patch is to move initialization of the
compute_node property to a new method called _init_compute_node()
That is called near the beginning of update_available_resource().

At the moment the update methods use a method parameter called
resources that is either the resources data structure obtained from
the virt driver or the compute_node property, depending on how it is
called. The result is always copied into the compute_node property.
This change initialises the compute_node property and creates the
compute node record as an initialisation step.

Moving the initialization of the compute_node property to the start
of update_available_resources() paves the way for the next patch in
this series to use it consistently in the update methods. The
code will then be ready to introduce the ComputeNode object.

This patch also fixes bug 1415768

commit_message:
Move ComputeNode creation at init stage in ResourceTracker

This is the first step in a series refactoring code that uses
ResourceTracker.compute_node so that it can later be changed
to be a ComputeNode object. Note that in this patch compute_node
is still a dict.

The main refactor in this patch is to move initialization of the
compute_node property to a new method called _init_compute_node()
That is called near the beginning of update_available_resource().

At the moment the update methods use a method parameter called
resources that is either the resources data structure obtained from
the virt driver or the compute_node property, depending on how it is
called. The result is always copied into the compute_node property.
This change initialises the compute_node property and creates the
compute node record as an initialisation step.

Moving the initialization of the compute_node property to the start
of update_available_resources() paves the way for the next patch in
this series to use it consistently in the update methods. The
code will then be ready to introduce the ComputeNode object.

This patch also fixes bug 1415768

Co-Authored-By: Sylvain Bauza <sbauza@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Ed Leafe <ed@leafe.com>

(cherry picked from commit c3ffcd18d9fb1d999d6fa360a811b4c7fdcaba13)

Conflicts:
	nova/compute/resource_tracker.py
	nova/tests/pci/test_pci_manager.py
	nova/tests/unit/compute/test_tracker.py

Closes-bug #1415768
Closes-bug #1383465

Change-Id: Ic04af76c3835a5bf63a42163d0335d6c7e26d68a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/26/173226/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.i18n import _, _LI, _LW def _init_compute_node(self, context, resources): """Initialise the compute node if it does not already exist. The resource tracker will be inoperable if compute_node is not defined. The compute_node will remain undefined if we fail to create it or if there is no associated service registered. If this method has to create a compute node it needs initial values - these come from resources. :param context: security context :param resources: initial values """ # if there is already a compute node we don't # need to do anything if self.compute_node: return # TODO(pmurray): this lookup should be removed when the service_id # field in the compute node goes away. At the moment it is deprecated # but still a required field, so it has to be assigned below. service = self._get_service(context) if not service: # no service record, disable resource return # now try to get the compute node record from the # database. If we get one we are done. self.compute_node = self._get_compute_node(context, service) if self.compute_node: return # there was no local copy and none in the database # so we need to create a new compute node. This needs # to be initialised with resource values. cn = {} cn.update(resources) # TODO(pmurray) service_id is deprecated but is still a required field. # This should be removed when the field is changed. cn['service_id'] = service['id'] cn['host'] = self.host # initialize load stats from existing instances: self._write_ext_resources(cn) # NOTE(pmurray): the stats field is stored as a json string. The # json conversion will be done automatically by the ComputeNode object # so this can be removed when using ComputeNode. cn['stats'] = jsonutils.dumps(cn['stats']) # pci_passthrough_devices may be in resources but are not # stored in compute nodes cn.pop('pci_passthrough_devices', None) self.compute_node = self.conductor_api.compute_node_create(context, cn) LOG.info(_LI('Compute_service record created for ' '%(host)s:%(node)s'), {'host': self.host, 'node': self.nodename}) self._update_available_resource(context, resources) # initialise the compute node object, creating it # if it does not already exist. self._init_compute_node(context, resources) # if we could not init the compute node the tracker will be # disabled and we should quit now if self.disabled: return self._update(context, resources) LOG.info(_LI('Compute_service record updated for %(host)s:%(node)s'), {'host': self.host, 'node': self.nodename}) def _get_compute_node(self, context, service): """Returns compute node for the host and nodename.""" compute_node_refs = service['compute_node'] if compute_node_refs: for cn in compute_node_refs: if cn.get('hypervisor_hostname') == self.nodename: return cn LOG.warning(_LW("No compute node record for %(host)s:%(node)s"), {'host': self.host, 'node': self.nodename})
deleted_lines: from nova.i18n import _ return self._update_available_resource(context, resources) self._sync_compute_node(context, resources) def _sync_compute_node(self, context, resources): """Create or update the compute node DB record.""" if not self.compute_node: # we need a copy of the ComputeNode record: service = self._get_service(context) if not service: # no service record, disable resource return compute_node_refs = service['compute_node'] if compute_node_refs: for cn in compute_node_refs: if cn.get('hypervisor_hostname') == self.nodename: self.compute_node = cn if self.pci_tracker: self.pci_tracker.set_compute_node_id(cn['id']) break if not self.compute_node: # Need to create the ComputeNode record: resources['service_id'] = service['id'] self._create(context, resources) if self.pci_tracker: self.pci_tracker.set_compute_node_id(self.compute_node['id']) LOG.info(_('Compute_service record created for %(host)s:%(node)s') % {'host': self.host, 'node': self.nodename}) else: # just update the record: self._update(context, resources) LOG.info(_('Compute_service record updated for %(host)s:%(node)s') % {'host': self.host, 'node': self.nodename}) def _create(self, context, values): """Create the compute node in the DB.""" # initialize load stats from existing instances: self._write_ext_resources(values) # NOTE(pmurray): the stats field is stored as a json string. The # json conversion will be done automatically by the ComputeNode object # so this can be removed when using ComputeNode. values['stats'] = jsonutils.dumps(values['stats']) self.compute_node = self.conductor_api.compute_node_create(context, values) # NOTE(sbauza): We don't want to miss the first creation event self._update_resource_stats(context, values)

commit_message:
Disable syncs to libs to unjam master requirements changes

We need to disable syncs and checks of requirements in libraries so we
can release updated versions of all libs that have no capped
requirements. We can restore the syncs when that is done, and then we'll
look into ways to update the tools to not update caps on library
projects.

http://logs.openstack.org/24/173924/1/check/check-tempest-dsvm-full/6c09e06/logs/devstacklog.txt.gz#_2015-04-15_23_02_58_575

Change-Id: Ib948b756b8e6ca47a4c9c44c48031e54b7386a06

commit_message:
Add utility functions to convert between and PEM and DER

Adding utility routines to convert the format of public and private
keys between PEM and DER format, using only the pyOpenSSL and pyCrypto libraries.
These routines support PKCS#8.  The unit tests verify that the inputs and
outputs are identical with the equivalent openssl cli commands.

Change-Id: I27480088a5c441e1d2e66354cc08e9a27d7c3f18
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/78/174178/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from Crypto.PublicKey import RSA from OpenSSL import crypto def convert_private_pem_to_der(pem): pkey = crypto.load_privatekey(crypto.FILETYPE_PEM, pem) pem = crypto.dump_privatekey(crypto.FILETYPE_ASN1, pkey) return pem def convert_private_der_to_pkcs8(der): private_key = RSA.importKey(der) pkcs8 = private_key.exportKey('PEM', pkcs=8) return pkcs8 def convert_public_pem_to_der(pem): pubkey = RSA.importKey(pem) der = pubkey.exportKey('DER') return der def convert_public_der_to_pem(der): pubkey = RSA.importKey(der) pem = pubkey.exportKey('PEM') return pem

commit_message:
Fix handling of payload_content_encoding for orders

The Barbican API defines three payload related fields:
   payload: the data in the current message
   payload_content_type: optional, but required if there is a payload
   payload_content_encoding: optional, but required if the type requires it

None of the three current order types use payload as an input.
Therefore, orders that include a payload should fail.  For valid orders,
payload_content_type and payload_content_encoding, if included, are
meaningless and can be ignored.

This commit:
   Adds checks to validate that orders do not send a payload,
   Removes the checks that previously required or validated,
        payload_content_encoding, and
   Updates the test cases accordingly.

Closes-bug: #1443058
Change-Id: I3cfee14bc51060100f300de292648f5477a4adb5

subject: compute: stop handling virt lifecycle events in cleanup_host()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-15 20:00:03.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_mgr.py', 'nova/compute/manager.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d1fb8d0fbdd6cb95c43b02f754409f1c728e8cd0', 'message': "compute: stop handling virt lifecycle events in cleanup_host()

When rebooting a compute host, guest VMs can be getting shutdown
automatically by the hypervisor and the virt driver is sending events to
the compute manager to handle them. If the compute service is still up
while this happens it will try to call the stop API to power off the
instance and update the database to show the instance as stopped.

When the compute service comes back up and events come in from the virt
driver that the guest VMs are running, nova will see that the vm_state
on the instance in the nova database is STOPPED and shut down the
instance by calling the stop API (basically ignoring what the virt
driver / hypervisor tells nova is the state of the guest VM).

Alternatively, if the compute service shuts down after changing the
intance task_state to 'powering-off' but before the stop API cast is
complete, the instance can be in a strange vm_state/task_state
combination that requires the admin to manually reset the task_state to
recover the instance.

Let's just try to avoid some of this mess by disconnecting the event
handling when the compute service is shutting down like we do for
neutron VIF plugging events. There could still be races here if the
compute service is shutting down after the hypervisor (e.g. libvirtd),
but this is at least a best attempt to do the mitigate the potential
damage.

Closes-Bug: #1444630
Related-Bug: #1293480
Related-Bug: #1408176

Change-Id: I1a321371dff7933cdd11d31d9f9c2a2f850fd8d9
"}]
commit_message:
compute: stop handling virt lifecycle events in cleanup_host()

When rebooting a compute host, guest VMs can be getting shutdown
automatically by the hypervisor and the virt driver is sending events to
the compute manager to handle them. If the compute service is still up
while this happens it will try to call the stop API to power off the
instance and update the database to show the instance as stopped.

When the compute service comes back up and events come in from the virt
driver that the guest VMs are running, nova will see that the vm_state
on the instance in the nova database is STOPPED and shut down the
instance by calling the stop API (basically ignoring what the virt
driver / hypervisor tells nova is the state of the guest VM).

Alternatively, if the compute service shuts down after changing the
intance task_state to 'powering-off' but before the stop API cast is
complete, the instance can be in a strange vm_state/task_state
combination that requires the admin to manually reset the task_state to
recover the instance.

Let's just try to avoid some of this mess by disconnecting the event
handling when the compute service is shutting down like we do for
neutron VIF plugging events. There could still be races here if the
compute service is shutting down after the hypervisor (e.g. libvirtd),
but this is at least a best attempt to do the mitigate the potential
damage.

Closes-Bug: #1444630
Related-Bug: #1293480
Related-Bug: #1408176

Change-Id: I1a321371dff7933cdd11d31d9f9c2a2f850fd8d9

commit_message:
Clean up unused stable-compat jobs configuration

Neither the stable-compat job group nor the templates they define
are used any longer, so remove them any any instantiations thereof.
Also remove a stray voting override for one of these jobs left
behind in the zuul layout.

Change-Id: Ia40d8cbf8cef803617509aeca20a9f1ec79d0880

commit_message:
process: add new section History

History are used to make easy users to follow the
evolution of the spec.

The spec can differ with the time, and the design can be updated
it should be important for users who use the spec has a documentation
to see those changes without to use a third tool.

The initial proposal is to add an entry for each update provided to
the spec (even fixing a typo) but we can restrain it only for changes
in the design or new contributor refered...

Change-Id: I13b8e09d5d7848ee4657214a86d2b48bf1b05e2a

Co-Authored-By: Dave McCowan <dmccowan@cisco.com>
'}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2015-04-15 20:13:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/barbican/commit/acc4dfc99d981dfb3dd107330584cd9d775395cb', 'message': 'Fix base64 decoding of payloads in one-step POST

Fix the way that normalization was handling base64 encoding in a
one-step POST secret creation.

Previous to this CR, PEM payloads in a one-step POST with
payload_content_encoding="base64" were being converted to DER form,
which was inconsistent with the way content-encoding works with other
secret types.

This CR requires that PEM payloads be base64 encoded in their entirety
to be included in a one-step POST.

This also means that when a PEM payload is passed to the secret_store it
will be base64 encoded in its entirety, so secret stores that need to
use DER forms need to make the conversion internally in the plugin.
I will add the changes for the KMIP secret store in a follow-up CR.

Barbican core also expects PEM formatted payloads that have been base64
encoded back from the secret_store during a get, so those changes are
made as well.

Fixes-Bug: #1441866
Change-Id: Ifbe021729a14f18fddd05991f6f96e49fbcf5c01
Co-Authored-By: Dave McCowan <dmccowan@cisco.com>

Fix the way that normalization was handling base64 encoding in a
one-step POST secret creation.

Previous to this CR, PEM payloads in a one-step POST with

which was inconsistent with the way content-encoding works with other
secret types.

This CR requires that PEM payloads be base64 encoded in their entirety

commit_message:
Fix base64 decoding of payloads in one-step POST

Fix the way that normalization was handling base64 encoding in a
one-step POST secret creation.

Previous to this CR, PEM payloads in a one-step POST with
payload_content_encoding="base64" were being converted to DER form,
which was inconsistent with the way content-encoding works with other
secret types.

This CR requires that PEM payloads be base64 encoded in their entirety
to be included in a one-step POST.

This also means that when a PEM payload is passed to the secret_store it
will be base64 encoded in its entirety, so secret stores that need to
use DER forms need to make the conversion internally in the plugin.
I will add the changes for the KMIP secret store in a follow-up CR.

Barbican core also expects PEM formatted payloads that have been base64
encoded back from the secret_store during a get, so those changes are
made as well.

Fixes-Bug: #1441866
Change-Id: Ifbe021729a14f18fddd05991f6f96e49fbcf5c01
Co-Authored-By: Dave McCowan <dmccowan@cisco.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/96/173396/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: data is simply converted to Base64. :param str unencrypted: Raw payload :param str content_type: The media type for the payload :param str content_encoding: Transfer encoding :param str secret_type: The type of secret :param bool enforce_text_only: Require text content_type or base64 content_encoding :returns: Tuple containing the normalized (base64 encoded) payload and the normalized media type. unencrypted_bytes = unencrypted.encode('utf-8') b64payload = base64.b64encode(unencrypted_bytes) elif normalized_mime in mime_types.BINARY: if not content_encoding: b64payload = base64.b64encode(unencrypted) elif content_encoding.lower() == 'base64': try: base64.b64decode(unencrypted) b64payload = unencrypted return b64payload, normalized_mime
deleted_lines: data is simply converted to Base64. In addition if the secret type is one of private, public, or certificate then the PEM headers are added to the Base64 encoding. unencrypted = unencrypted.encode('utf-8') unencrypted = base64.b64encode(unencrypted) else: if content_encoding: content_encoding = content_encoding.lower() if content_encoding == 'base64': b64payload = unencrypted if is_pem_payload(unencrypted): pem_components = get_pem_components(unencrypted) b64payload = pem_components[1] try: base64.b64decode(b64payload) elif mime_types.use_binary_content_as_is(content_type, content_encoding): if (secret_type == s.SecretType.PRIVATE or secret_type == s.SecretType.PUBLIC or secret_type == s.SecretType.CERTIFICATE): unencrypted = to_pem(secret_type, unencrypted) else: unencrypted = base64.b64encode(unencrypted) return unencrypted, normalized_mime

commit_message:
FWaaS: Remove check for bash usage

Like Neutron, removing the check for bash script usage and
changed bash scripts to use '#!/usr/bin/env bash'.

Change-Id: Id0a74c1a976c06c66ebb370d0d9e17de17dc5231
Closes-Bug: #1441632

commit_message:
[install-guide] [yum] install libvirt-daemon-kvm before starting libvirtd

Before starting the libvirtd service it is necessary to install the
libvirt-daemon-kvm package. Libvirt is not installed as a dependency of
openstack-nova-compute.

Partially implements bp installguide-kilo.

Change-Id: I530da649ad806a4ac3e578d1e8f542b547c41539

commit_message:
Fix rebuild of an instance with a volume attached

When detaching block devices on rebuild we only notify Cinder it's
safe to detach a volume, but don't actually tell the driver to do
that first.

Closes-Bug: #1440762

Change-Id: I017bf749f426717dc76cf99a387102848fb1c541

commit_message:
let fake virt track resources

For building scheduling test cases we need the fake virt driver to
actually track the allocated resources to trigger scheduler out of
resource logic. This provides a simple allocator / deallocator model
for that.

(cherry picked from commit e6cbfa33f3ebde617d5bdba39bd44eb9c528ce92)

Conflicts:
	nova/virt/fake.py

Partial-bug #1383465 (relevant to Juno only)
Change-Id: Ifa006f70b9bbb0c0b2a5db066e1ba87aa1b50b34
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/00/174300/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class Resources(object): vcpus = 0 memory_mb = 0 local_gb = 0 vcpus_used = 0 memory_mb_used = 0 local_gb_used = 0 def __init__(self, vcpus=8, memory_mb=8000, local_gb=500): self.vcpus = vcpus self.memory_mb = memory_mb self.local_gb = local_gb def claim(self, vcpus=0, mem=0, disk=0): self.vcpus_used += vcpus self.memory_mb_used += mem self.local_gb_used += disk def release(self, vcpus=0, mem=0, disk=0): self.vcpus_used -= vcpus self.memory_mb_used -= mem self.local_gb_used -= disk def dump(self): return { 'vcpus': self.vcpus, 'memory_mb': self.memory_mb, 'local_gb': self.local_gb, 'vcpus_used': self.vcpus_used, 'memory_mb_used': self.memory_mb_used, 'local_gb_used': self.local_gb_used } self.resources = Resources( vcpus=self.vcpus, memory_mb=self.memory_mb, local_gb=self.local_gb) self.host_status_base = { self.resources.claim( vcpus=instance.get('vcpus') or 0, mem=instance.get('memory_mb') or 0, disk=instance['root_gb'] or 0) self.resources.release( vcpus=instance.get('vcpus') or 0, mem=instance.get('memory_mb') or 0, disk=instance.get('root_gb') or 0) host_status.update(self.resources.dump())

commit_message:
[install-guide] make creation of Keystone user copy & paste compatible

Note that it is possible to prompt for the password when creating a new
Keystone user and add instructions that directly be used to create a new
Keystone user.

Change-Id: I3a406a12321b1bbef4a465096fafd85b2dac8e77

subject: Pin puppetlabs-concat to 1.2.1 in fixtures
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-16 08:26:16.000000000', 'files': ['.fixtures.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-swift/commit/1e4ebee1e88f946dfe4ed078437dc20b28698b53', 'message': 'Pin puppetlabs-concat to 1.2.1 in fixtures

Puppet Labs is in the process of releasing a 2.0.0 version of
puppetlabs-concat, which will have many breaking changes that affect
many dependent modules. Changes have been merged to master, but not yet
released. While we figure out what changes we need to make in our own
modules and wait for updates in dependent modules, we should just pin
to a stable version.

Change-Id: Ifb4ca49a9dcbeb3b20781ed24ecd16ae9348903b
(cherry picked from commit 2737af141ac88a07cda39e402dacb4275792aa8f)

commit_message:
Pin puppetlabs-concat to 1.2.1 in fixtures

Puppet Labs is in the process of releasing a 2.0.0 version of
puppetlabs-concat, which will have many breaking changes that affect
many dependent modules. Changes have been merged to master, but not yet
released. While we figure out what changes we need to make in our own
modules and wait for updates in dependent modules, we should just pin
to a stable version.

Change-Id: Ifb4ca49a9dcbeb3b20781ed24ecd16ae9348903b
(cherry picked from commit 2737af141ac88a07cda39e402dacb4275792aa8f)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-swift refs/changes/50/174250/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

'}, {'number': 18, 'created': '2015-03-03 19:20:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/175a10691692d3f3cac1d0a4d72feee2dc647993', 'message': 'support for keystone v3 api

This is based on the blueprint:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/150108/

With keystone v3, user and project resources have to be domain aware.
When using the v3 api (either a url which ends in /v3, or using
--os-identity-api-version 3), with the openstack client,
you must either:
1) Specify the domain using the --domain argument.  You may specify
either a name or an ID.  The openstack client will do a search to
lookup the ID given a name, so if you know the ID you can save a round
trip.  This is especially required for create e.g.
 openstack user create name --domain domain
Users and projects exist inside domains.  You cannot create a user or
a project without specifying the domain that it is in.
2) Use the user and project ID instead of the name.  With keystone v3,
IDs are global - they uniquely identify resources.  You cannot have
two users in different domains with the same ID.

In puppet, resource names/titles must be unique.  In order to make user
and project resources unique and specify the domain at the same time,
the delimiter "::" has been introduced.  For example:
 keystone_user { "username::domainname" }
specifies a user in a domain.  Same with keystone_tenant and
keystone_user_role.  For keystone_user_role, since keystone v3 allows
you to create a role on a domain, there is a special syntax:
 keystone_user_role { "username::userdomain@::roledomain" }
Note that to the left of roledomain there is no project name.  This means
it is just a domain name, and the role should be assigned on the domain
rather than on a project.
For resources which also have a domain parameter, the domain parameter
will override a domain given in a resource name.
Change-Id: Iaf25d6e5e24674763918b543e705a60f26ff4e1a

--os-identity-api-version 3), with the openstack client,
you must either:
1) Specify the domain using the --domain argument.  You may specify
either a name or an ID.  The openstack client will do a search to
lookup the ID given a name, so if you know the ID you can save a round
trip.  This is especially required for create e.g.
 openstack user create name --domain domain
Users and projects exist inside domains.  You cannot create a user or
a project without specifying the domain that it is in.
2) Use the user and project ID instead of the name.  With keystone v3,
IDs are global - they uniquely identify resources.  You cannot have
two users in different domains with the same ID.

In puppet, resource names/titles must be unique.  In order to make user
and project resources unique and specify the domain at the same time,
the delimiter "::" has been introduced.  For example:
 keystone_user { "username::domainname" }
specifies a user in a domain.  Same with keystone_tenant and
keystone_user_role.  For keystone_user_role, since keystone v3 allows
you to create a role on a domain, there is a special syntax:
 keystone_user_role { "username::userdomain@::roledomain" }
Note that to the left of roledomain there is no project name.  This means
it is just a domain name, and the role should be assigned on the domain
rather than on a project.
For resources which also have a domain parameter, the domain parameter
will override a domain given in a resource name.
Change-Id: Iaf25d6e5e24674763918b543e705a60f26ff4e1a

commit_message:
support for keystone v3 api

Implements: blueprint api-v3-support

With keystone v3, user and project resources have to be domain aware.
When using the v3 api (either a url which ends in /v3, or using
--os-identity-api-version 3), with the openstack client,
you must either:
1) Specify the domain using the --domain argument.  You may specify
either a name or an ID.  The openstack client will do a search to
lookup the ID given a name, so if you know the ID you can save a round
trip.  This is especially required for create e.g.
 openstack user create name --domain domain
Users and projects exist inside domains.  You cannot create a user or
a project without specifying the domain that it is in.
2) Use the user and project ID instead of the name.  With keystone v3,
IDs are global - they uniquely identify resources.  You cannot have
two users in different domains with the same ID.

In puppet, resource names/titles must be unique.  In order to make user
and project resources unique and specify the domain at the same time,
the delimiter "::" has been introduced.  For example:
 keystone_user { "username::domainname" }
specifies a user in a domain.  Same with keystone_tenant and
keystone_user_role.  For keystone_user_role, since keystone v3 allows
you to create a role on a domain, there is a special syntax:
 keystone_user_role { "username::userdomain@::roledomain" }
Note that to the left of roledomain there is no project name.  This means
it is just a domain name, and the role should be assigned on the domain
rather than on a project.
For resources which also have a domain parameter, the domain parameter
will override a domain given in a resource name.

There is a hidden "backdoor" way to specify the default domain to use
when installing on a non-keystone system and there is no access to the
default_domain_id in keystone.conf.  Create the file /tmp/.domain like this:

[DEFAULT]
default_domain_name=Default
default_domain_id=default

or use whatever your actual default domain name and id are.

Change-Id: Iaf25d6e5e24674763918b543e705a60f26ff4e1a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone refs/changes/26/146926/21 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: newproperty(:domain) do newvalues(/\S+/) end

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-doc refs/changes/92/172992/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <section xmlns="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" version="5.0" xml:id="identity-policies"> <?dbhtml stop-chunking?> <title>Policies</title> <para>Each OpenStack service has a policy file in JSON format, called <filename>policy.json</filename>. The policy file specifies rules, and the rule that governs each resource. A resource could be API access, the ability to attach to a volume, or to fire up instances.</para> <para>The policies can be updated by the cloud administrator to further control access to the various resources. The middleware could also be further customized. Note that your users must be assigned to groups/roles that you refer to in your policies.</para> <para>Below is a snippet of the Block Storage service <filename>policy.json</filename> file.</para> <programlisting language="json"><xi:include href="http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/openstack-manuals/plain/doc/common/samples/policy.json" parse="text"/></programlisting> <para>Note the <emphasis role="bold">default</emphasis> rule specifies that the user must be either an admin or the owner of the volume. It essentially says only the owner of a volume or the admin may create/delete/update volumes. Certain other operations such as managing volume types are accessible only to admin users.</para> </section>

commit_message:
Sync latest _i18n module for os_brick

The _i18n module in os_brick is out of date.
It is still using the old oslo.i18n namespace
for the i18n library instead of oslo_i18n.

This patch syncs in the latest incubator code to
correct that.

Current HEAD in OSLO:
---------------------
commit:  9117130d7e73a18f0720ecb264a0a85aa26d3816
Date:  Fri Apr 10 11:39:29 2015 +0200
Test loopingcall and threadgroup on Python 3

Changes merged with this patch:
--------------------------------
0cc741a9 - switch to oslo_i18n

Change-Id: I76d1b2449c75fbd7a4a38bffdbdf492c98f639b1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-brick refs/changes/96/174096/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import oslo_i18n _translators = oslo_i18n.TranslatorFactory(domain='os_brick')

commit_message:
Shuffle of the order of BIND9 masters

Make sure that the masters given to BIND9 on an addzone are shuffled
so that different MiniDNS instances are targetted for AXFRs for different
zones

Change-Id: Id01815f8d70fa50e83f0c6bee52894b885788e49
Closes-Bug: 1444414

commit_message:
Send router_interface add/remove calls to ODL

These calls were not being sent by the L3 router plugin.

Change-Id: I63d83a7449947ac2fb40a802cd92dea9702d5934
Closes-Bug: #1444769
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/84/174184/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def add_router_interface(self, context, router_id, interface_info): new_router = super( OpenDaylightL3RouterPlugin, self).create_router_interface( context, router_id, interface_info) url = ROUTERS + "/" + router_id + "/add_router_interface" self.client.sendjson('post', url, {ROUTERS[:-1]: new_router}) return new_router def remove_router_interface(self, context, router_id, interface_info): new_router = super( OpenDaylightL3RouterPlugin, self).delete_router_interface( context, router_id, interface_info) url = ROUTERS + "/" + router_id + "/remove_router_interface" self.client.sendjson('delete', url, None) return new_router

commit_message:
Update interface settings only in updated node

Since Fuel has denied update interface config in ready nodes we should
update configuration of interfaces only on bootstrap nodes

Change-Id: I73c4957e06b459dec9d8dd3c94d7500331f0718e
Closes-bug: #1440687

commit_message:
Fix for API job post bug

* previous patch broke job being posted to job board backend
  from the API
* Removing new way to omit None fields from being returned by api, this 
  will have to be revised for an optimized design

Change-Id: I2b0ef90ea9290dccc181511c63f63cae8c16d2cc
Partial-Bug: #1444758

deleted_lines: if kwargs.get(k) is None: setattr(self, k, wtypes.Unset) else: setattr(self, k, kwargs.get(k))

commit_message:
Use oslo_log instead of openstack.common.log

oslo_log should be used instead of oslo-incubator.
This fixes an error "oslo_config.cfg.DuplicateOptError:
duplicate option: default_log_levels" when os-brick is imported
to projects using oslo_config and oslo_log.

Change-Id: Ic38c548bd39bc8ce68bd70d2b0693f6d0c0c5399
Closes-Bug: #1443681
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-brick refs/changes/06/173106/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_log import log as logging
deleted_lines: from os_brick.openstack.common import log as logging

commit_message:
Merge flavor response schema into one file

After removing v3 schemas, we have only 1 set of schemas for v2 (/v2.1)
APIs but those end up in scattered structure.

Schema files needs to be re arranged into a clean structure. Any
resource schema should be defined in single file for better readability.

This patch merge the flavor response schema into one file.

Partially implements blueprint rearrange-nova-response-schemas

Change-Id: I2f660ce072fe199b4ed4d51ac2267b871d82ef83

'required': ['flavors'], 'additionalProperties': False, } } common_flavor_info = { 'type': 'object', 'properties': { 'name': {'type': 'string'}, 'links': parameter_types.links, 'ram': {'type': 'integer'}, 'vcpus': {'type': 'integer'}, 'swap': {'type': 'integer'}, 'disk': {'type': 'integer'}, 'id': {'type': 'string'} }, 'required': ['name', 'links', 'ram', 'vcpus', 'swap', 'disk', 'id'], 'additionalProperties': False, } common_flavor_list_details = { 'status_code': [200], 'response_body': { 'type': 'object', 'properties': { 'flavors': { 'type': 'array', 'items': common_flavor_info } }, 'required': ['flavors'], 'additionalProperties': False, } } common_flavor_details = { 'status_code': [200], 'response_body': { 'type': 'object', 'properties': { 'flavor': common_flavor_info }, 'required': ['flavor'], 'additionalProperties': False, } }

commit_message:
Rearrange keypairs response schema into one file

After removing v3 schemas, we have only 1 set of schemas for v2 (/v2.1)
APIs but those end up in scattered structure.

Schema files needs to be re arranged into a clean structure. Any
resource schema should be defined in single file for better readability.

This patch rearrange the keypairs response schema into one file.

Partially implements blueprint rearrange-nova-response-schemas

Change-Id: I76ed40fbe4999c3ee84c4377a6f14fc3a2a11061

commit_message:
fix bug in openstack-network-compute.pp

Limitation 'Nova_config<| |> -> Service['nova-network']' has a sense
only when multi_host == true. Moved this to corresponding branch of
the if $multi_host conditional.

Change-Id: Ie293b06c92e97bd101c616827fee25ff2e795791
Closes-bug: 1444122

added_lines: class OSwLRequestTemplate(BaseRequestTemplate): def __init__(self, max_logs_count=30): BaseRequestTemplate.__init__(self) self.max_logs_count = max_logs_count self.url = "/api/v1/oswl_stats/" self.resources = ['vm', 'tenant', 'volume', 'security_group', 'keystone_user', 'flavor', 'cluster_stats'] def get_request_body(self): master_node_uid = self.random_sha data = {'oswl_stats': []} for id in xrange(0, self.max_logs_count): oswl_stat = { 'master_node_uid': master_node_uid, "id": id, "cluster_id": random.randint(1, 999), 'creation_date': str(datetime.datetime.now()), 'update_time': str(datetime.datetime.now()), 'resource_type': random.choice(self.resources), 'resource_checksum': self.random_sha, 'resource_data': { 'added': {}, 'current': [], 'removed': {}, 'modified': {} } } data['oswl_stats'].append(oswl_stat) return json.dumps(data)

commit_message:
Arrange quotas response schema into one file

After removing v3 schemas, we have only 1 set of schemas for v2 (/v2.1)
APIs but those end up in scattered structure.

Schema files needs to be re arranged into a clean structure. Any
resource schema should be defined in single file for better readability.

This patch merge quotas response schema into one file.
Also rename schema names according to their API.

Partially implements blueprint rearrange-nova-response-schemas

Change-Id: I2378e019353f551a3ac49666edd5ecb561b5b6ed

commit_message:
Need WEBROOT in local_settings.py file

Horizon relies on the WEBROOT setting in order to handle
static resources.
